wikipedia_page.main: Philip Gurdon (born 1800 at Letton, Norfolk; died 1 August 1874 at Cranworth, Norfolk) was an English first-class cricketer associated with Norfolk who was active in the 1820s. He also played for Cambridge University. He is recorded in two matches, totalling 16 runs with a highest score of 9.Gurdon was educated at Eton, then went up to Trinity College, Cambridge, but after two years he moved to Downing College. After graduating he was ordained as a Church of England priest and was rector of parishes in Norfolk near his family's home at Letton Hall from 1825 until his death in 1874.

response: John Fawcett (1766/7–1849) was a Christ Church, Oxford graduate, the son of Richard Fawcett of Grendon. His change of surname to Pulteney was by royal licence, in 1813.s:Alumni Oxonienses: the Members of the University of Oxford, 1715-1886/Pulteney, John The couple had a son, John Apsley Pulteney of the 12th Lancers (1805/6–1840).s:Alumni Oxonienses: the Members of the University of Oxford, 1715-1886/Pulteney, John Apsley Their eldest daughter Henrietta Laura Pulteney (1804–1898) married in 1832 the Rev. Philip Gurdon, and was mother of General Evelyn Pulteney Gurdon.
|A single first-class appearance for Cambridge University. Brother of Philip Gurdon.
